newsitem.title: SWEDEN: One in five Swedes want to join EMU in 1999 - poll.
newsitem.headline: One in five Swedes want to join EMU in 1999 - poll.

text.p: Only one in every five Swedes wants Sweden to be in the first wave of countries to join Europe's economic and monetary union (EMU) from the beginning in January 1999, according to a poll published on Tuesday.
A survey by pollster Skop found 19 percent of respondents were in favour of early membership of EMU.
Almost a quarter of the 1,000 people questioned gave a flat no to EMU membership, according to the poll published by tabloid paper Aftonbladet.
The majority of Swedes wanted a happy medium.
A total of 55 percent of respondents wanted to wait and see how EMU developed before making a firm decision or were uncertain.

Women were generally more negative towards EMU than men with only one tenth of women interviewed wanting to join EMU from the start in 1999 while a quarter of the men questioned were in favour of early membership.

A January poll by the Swedish Institute of Public Opinion and Research (Sifo) found 23 percent of people surveyed were in favour of Sweden joining EMU at its start, compared to 18 percent in a similar survey in November.
The poll, published by financial daily Finanstidningen, showed 23 percent thought Sweden should join at a later stage, while 39 percent were opposed to membership and the rest undecided.
